Tax returns may be original or copies, but make sure there is a return for tax period covered by the examination report. Cases with return copies must have transcripts attached verifying the copies are accurate. The proposed employment tax adjustment must be presented to the to receive formal consideration in Appeals. The type of protest and the detail contained therein varies depending on the total tax and penalties proposed. The same rules used in income tax cases apply to the type of protest for employment tax cases. If the proposed increase or decrease in tax (including penalties) is more than $
per tax period, or the case is one of a few specific types (including employee plan and exempt organization cases), a formal written protest is required. See Publication
for the requirements of a formal protest. If the protested liability is not more than $

for each tax period at the only thing required is a written letter, requesting Appeals consideration indicating the issues and reasons for disagreement. This is considered a case request.” See Publication

When a formal, written protest is required, the examiner provides a separate, written rebuttal to the protest submitted by the taxpayer. This rebuttal serves supplement the information contained in the Revenue Agent’s Report (RAR) and resolve any factual differences between the RAR and the protest. It also provides constructive responses to the taxpayer’s written arguments.

The taxpayer may litigate other types of em- ployment tax cases, as well as those involving worker classification issues, either the United States District Court or the United States Court of Federal Claims. Before taxpayers can initiate suit in either of these courts, they will have to pay, at a minimum, the employment tax assessment attributable to employee for any one quarter and file a claim for refund of the tax. Once claim for refund is denied or

months elapse without any action by the Service, the taxpayer may initiate suit. Generally, Employment taxes are not subject to the jurisdiction of the U.S. Tax Court. However, self-employment taxes, Section
relief issues, and worker classification issues are subject the jurisdiction of the U.S. Tax Court. (

B — Enter the occupation and SSN of the person receiving these previously unreported wages.

IRC Section 6651(a)(1) - Failure to File Penalty
FUTA

Since you did not file your returns for the tax year ended December 31, 2002 within the time prescribed by law, and you did not show that such failure was due to reasonable cause and not due to willful neglect, a failure to file penalty of 5 percent is added to the tax for each month or part of a month (but not to exceed a total of 25 percent) for which your returns were late. See Section 6651(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. In addition, interest is computed on the penalty from the due date of the return (including any extensions). See page 2 of Exhibit B for computations.
FICA

Since you did not file your returns for the tax periods ended March 31, 2002, June 30, 2002, September 30, 2002, and December 31, 2002 within the time prescribed by law, and you did not show that such failure was due to reasonable cause and not due to willful neglect, a failure to file penalty of 5 percent is added to the tax for each month or part of a month (but not to exceed a total of 25 percent) for which your returns were late. See Section 6651(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. In addition, interest is computed on the penalty from the due date of the return (including any extensions). See page 2 of Exhibit B for computations.
